items.title: Food banks stretched thin amid government shutdown
items.standfirst: A pair of federal judges ruled that the Trump administration must tap into a contingency fund to continue making payments for SNAP, which was set to have its funding expire. Still, some food banks are already struggling to keep up with demand. Kati Weis reports.
items.content: A pair of federal judges ruled that the Trump administration must tap into a contingency fund to continue making payments for SNAP, which was set to have its funding expire. Still, some food banks are already struggling to keep up with demand. Kati Weis reports.

items.title: Trump administration blocked from suspending Snap benefits for millions of Americans
items.standfirst: One judge issued temporary restraining order while another judge ruled the government must continue to fund program that helps low-income householdsUS politics live – latest updatesTwo federal judges issued back-to-back rulings on Friday in separate cases ordering the Trump administration to use contingency funds to continue paying for food stamps during the government shutdown.A federal judge in Rhode Island on Friday afternoon blocked the Trump administration from suspending all food aid for millions of Americans, in a case brought by a group of US cities, non-profit organizations and a trade union. Continue reading...
items.content: One judge issued temporary restraining order while another judge ruled the government must continue to fund program that helps low-income householdsUS politics live – latest updatesTwo federal judges issued back-to-back rulings on Friday in separate cases ordering the Trump administration to use contingency funds to continue paying for food stamps during the government shutdown.A federal judge in Rhode Island on Friday afternoon blocked the Trump administration from suspending all food aid for millions of Americans, in a case brought by a group of US cities, non-profit organizations and a trade union. Continue reading...

items.title: Hundreds feared dead in days of protests after disputed Tanzanian elections
items.standfirst: Hundreds of people are feared dead after days of protests over Tanzania's disputed election, which incumbent President Samia Suluhu Hassan was declared to have won with nearly 98% of the vote.
items.content: Hundreds of people are feared dead after days of protests over Tanzania's disputed election, which incumbent President Samia Suluhu Hassan was declared to have won with nearly 98% of the vote.

items.title: Tanzania President Hassan wins disputed election amid deadly protests
items.standfirst: Tanzanian President Samia Suluhu Hassan won a landslide election victory, official results showed Saturday. The opposition Chadema party, barred from taking part in the poll, said that hundreds of people have been killed by security forces since protests broke out on election day on Wednesday.
items.content: Tanzanian President Samia Suluhu Hassan won a landslide election victory, official results showed Saturday. The opposition Chadema party, barred from taking part in the poll, said that hundreds of people have been killed by security forces since protests broke out on election day on Wednesday.

items.title: Tanzania’s Hassan declared landslide winner in election that triggered violent protests
items.standfirst: The result hands Hassan, who took power in 2021, a five-year term following opposition repressionTanzania’s president, Samia Suluhu Hassan, has been declared the winner of the country’s disputed election with more than 97% of the vote following violent protests across the country earlier in the week.The landslide result announced by Tanzania’s electoral commission hands Hassan, who took power in 2021 after the death in office of her predecessor, a five-year term to govern the east African country of 68 million people. Continue reading...
items.content: The result hands Hassan, who took power in 2021, a five-year term following opposition repressionTanzania’s president, Samia Suluhu Hassan, has been declared the winner of the country’s disputed election with more than 97% of the vote following violent protests across the country earlier in the week.The landslide result announced by Tanzania’s electoral commission hands Hassan, who took power in 2021 after the death in office of her predecessor, a five-year term to govern the east African country of 68 million people. clusters.title: Israel says latest remains returned from Gaza are not bodies of hostages

items.title: Israel says latest remains returned from Gaza are not bodies of hostages
items.standfirst: The Israeli military said Saturday that the remains of three people handed over by Hamas to the Red Cross this week do not belong to any of the remaining Israeli hostages. Palestinian militants have released the remains of 17 hostages they held in Gaza, but the handover of the bodies of the 11 remaining hostages has been slow.
items.content: The Israeli military said Saturday that the remains of three people handed over by Hamas to the Red Cross this week do not belong to any of the remaining Israeli hostages. Palestinian militants have released the remains of 17 hostages they held in Gaza, but the handover of the bodies of the 11 remaining hostages has been slow.

items.title: Era of free trade and investment is over, Canada’s PM tells Apec summit
items.standfirst: Mark Carney warns Asia-Pacific leaders global economy undergoing profound change, as China’s president mounts defence of free tradeThe Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney, has warned that the era of free trade and investment that formed the foundations of the postwar global economy has ended.In a stark message to Asia-Pacific leaders at the Apec summit in South Korea on Friday, Carney said rules-based open trade no longer worked in a global economy that was undergoing one of its most profound periods of change since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. Continue reading...
items.content: Mark Carney warns Asia-Pacific leaders global economy undergoing profound change, as China’s president mounts defence of free tradeThe Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney, has warned that the era of free trade and investment that formed the foundations of the postwar global economy has ended.In a stark message to Asia-Pacific leaders at the Apec summit in South Korea on Friday, Carney said rules-based open trade no longer worked in a global economy that was undergoing one of its most profound periods of change since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Canadian PM Mark Carney apologized to Trump over an ad.
The ad was from Ontario government and criticized Trump's trade policy.
Carney made the apology privately at a dinner.
Carney warned of profound change in the global economy.
Carney said the era of free trade is over.

clusters.title: UN Security Council supports Morocco’s plan for Western Sahara
clusters.neutral_headline: UN Security Council Supports Morocco's Western Sahara Plan

items.title: UN Security Council supports Morocco’s plan for Western Sahara
items.standfirst: The resolution supports Morocco's claim to the disputed Western Sahara, a stance backed by Trump's administration.
items.content: The resolution supports Morocco's claim to the disputed Western Sahara, a stance backed by Trump's administration.

items.title: UN Security Council backs Moroccan plan for disputed Western Sahara
items.standfirst: The UN Security Council approved a US-backed resolution on Friday supporting Morocco's continued control of the disputed Western Sahara, saying that "genuine autonomy under Moroccan sovereignty" could well be the most "feasible" option for the mineral-rich territory. The Algerian-backed Polisario Front continues to advocate independence for the former Spanish colony.
items.content: The UN Security Council approved a US-backed resolution on Friday supporting Morocco's continued control of the disputed Western Sahara, saying that "genuine autonomy under Moroccan sovereignty" could well be the most "feasible" option for the mineral-rich territory. The Algerian-backed Polisario Front continues to advocate independence for the former Spanish colony.

items.title: UN approves resolution supporting Morocco’s claim to Western Sahara
items.standfirst: Move is strongest endorsement yet for retained rule over disputed territory, despite fierce opposition from AlgeriaThe UN security council has approved a US-backed resolution supporting Morocco’s claim to the disputed Western Sahara, despite fierce opposition from Algeria.Although Friday’s vote was divided, the resolution offers the strongest endorsement yet for Morocco’s plan to keep sovereignty over the territory, which also has backing from most European Union members and a growing number of African allies. Continue reading...
items.content: Move is strongest endorsement yet for retained rule over disputed territory, despite fierce opposition from AlgeriaThe UN security council has approved a US-backed resolution supporting Morocco’s claim to the disputed Western Sahara, despite fierce opposition from Algeria.Although Friday’s vote was divided, the resolution offers the strongest endorsement yet for Morocco’s plan to keep sovereignty over the territory, which also has backing from most European Union members and a growing number of African allies. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The resolution supports Morocco's claim to Western Sahara.
The US-backed resolution was approved by the UN Security Council.
The resolution offers strong endorsement for Morocco's plan.
The Algerian-backed Polisario Front opposes the plan.
The vote was divided, but most EU members back the plan.

items.title: China says it will allow some Nexperia semiconductor chip exports to resume to ease critical supply shortages impacting global auto production
China to ease export ban of Nexperia semiconductors to Europe
items.standfirst: China said Saturday it will exempt some Nexperia computer chips from an export ban that threatened to seriously disrupt EU car production. European automakers had warned that shortages of chips supplied by Nexperia would force stoppages at production lines in Europe.
items.content: China said Saturday it will exempt some Nexperia computer chips from an export ban that threatened to seriously disrupt EU car production. European automakers had warned that shortages of chips supplied by Nexperia would force stoppages at production lines in Europe.

ai_summary: China will exempt some Nexperia computer chips from export ban.
The ban threatened to disrupt EU car production.
European automakers warned of production stoppages.

items.title: JP Morgan warned US of $1bn in Epstein transactions possibly related to human trafficking
items.standfirst: Bank says it alerted US of ‘suspicious’ transactions just weeks after paedophile was found dead in New York jail cellJP Morgan warned the US government about more than $1bn in transactions linked to Jeffrey Epstein that were possibly related to reports of human trafficking, new documents confirm.The largest bank in the US filed a suspicious activity report (SAR) in 2019, just weeks after Epstein was found dead in a New York jail cell, about transactions linked to the paedophile financier and prominent business figures. It also flagged wire transfers made by Epstein to Russian banks. Continue reading...
items.content: Bank says it alerted US of ‘suspicious’ transactions just weeks after paedophile was found dead in New York jail cellJP Morgan warned the US government about more than $1bn in transactions linked to Jeffrey Epstein that were possibly related to reports of human trafficking, new documents confirm.The largest bank in the US filed a suspicious activity report (SAR) in 2019, just weeks after Epstein was found dead in a New York jail cell, about transactions linked to the paedophile financier and prominent business figures. It also flagged wire transfers made by Epstein to Russian banks. Continue reading...

ai_summary: JP Morgan alerted the US government about transactions.
The transactions were linked to Jeffrey Epstein.
The transactions totaled over one billion dollars.
The bank filed a suspicious activity report in 2019.
Epstein was found dead weeks after the report.

clusters.title: Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, the commoner formerly known as 'prince', faces an uncertain future
clusters.neutral_headline: Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, the commoner formerly known as 'prince', faces an uncertain future:

items.title: Andrew Mountbatten Windsor, the commoner formerly known as 'prince', faces an uncertain future
items.standfirst: Andrew Mountbatten Windsor has been stripped of his remaining royal titles in the wake of mounting scandals over his relationship with late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and allegations of sexual abuse against the two men. The former prince was no longer listed on the official roll of the peerage as of Friday.
items.content: Andrew Mountbatten Windsor has been stripped of his remaining royal titles in the wake of mounting scandals over his relationship with late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and allegations of sexual abuse against the two men. items.title: King Charles to remove Prince Andrew's titles and eject him from the Royal Lodge

clusters.title: Senate passes bill to nullify Trump’s sweeping global tariffs on more than 100 nations – as it happened
clusters.neutral_headline: Senate passes bill to nullify Trump’s sweeping global tariffs on more than 100 nations – as it happened:

items.title: Senate passes bill to nullify Trump’s sweeping global tariffs on more than 100 nations – as it happened
items.standfirst: This live blog is now closed.Trump news at a glance: Four Senate Republicans join Democrats to reject global tariffsIn the days leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting, American officials signalled that the US president did not intend to make good on a recent threat to impose an additional 100% import tax on Chinese goods.Also that China had shown signs it is willing to relax its export controls on rare earths as well as revive buying soybeans from the US.The relationship with China is very good.Because of the tremendous destructive power, I HATED to do it, but had no choice! Russia is second, and China is a distant third, but will be even within 5 years.Because of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately. Continue reading...
items.content: This live blog is now closed.Trump news at a glance: Four Senate Republicans join Democrats to reject global tariffsIn the days leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting, American officials signalled that the US president did not intend to make good on a recent threat to impose an additional 100% import tax on Chinese goods.Also that China had shown signs it is willing to relax its export controls on rare earths as well as revive buying soybeans from the US.The relationship with China is very good.Because of the tremendous destructive power, I HATED to do it, but had no choice! Russia is second, and China is a distant third, but will be even within 5 years.Because of other countries testing programs, I have instructed the Department of War to start testing our Nuclear Weapons on an equal basis. That process will begin immediately. Continue reading...

items.title: US Senate votes to reject Trump’s global tariffs on more than 100 countries
items.standfirst: Vote passes 51-47 in latest bipartisan effort to challenge tariffs, but House is unlikely to take any similar actionThe US Senate took a stand against Donald Trump’s global tariffs affecting more than 100 countries on Thursday, voting to nullify the so-called “reciprocal” tariffs.Four Republicans joined with all Democrats to vote 51-47 on a resolution to end the base-level tariffs that the president put into place via executive order. Continue reading...
items.content: Vote passes 51-47 in latest bipartisan effort to challenge tariffs, but House is unlikely to take any similar actionThe US Senate took a stand against Donald Trump’s global tariffs affecting more than 100 countries on Thursday, voting to nullify the so-called “reciprocal” tariffs.Four Republicans joined with all Democrats to vote 51-47 on a resolution to end the base-level tariffs that the president put into place via executive order. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Senate passed a bill to reject tariffs.
The tariffs affected over 100 nations.
Four Republicans joined Democrats in the vote.
The vote was 51-47.
The House is unlikely to take similar action.
